title-group.article-title: Prediction of three-dimensional composite laminate response using micromechanics of failure

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Sung Kyu Ha, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hanyang University, #1271, Sa 1-dong, Sangnok-gu, Ansan-si, Gyeonggi-do 426-791, Korea Email: sungha@hanyang.ac.kr

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: A three-dimensional micromechanics of failure model was developed and applied in order to predict triaxial failure envelopes and stress–strain curves for 12 test cases in the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II), which involves five continuous fiber–matrix laminates and multi-axial loadings, including those in through-thickness direction. The micromechanics of failure is based on micromechanical unit cell models, which characterize the microstructure of composites, and consists of independent constituent failure criteria and a progressive damage model for the matrix. Nonlinear ply behavior in the matrix-dominant directions was successfully simulated. Thermal stresses were also considered. Results of prediction were presented together with an explanation of the phenomena.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: During the past half-century, many research efforts have been dedicated to investigating failure mechanisms for composite materials. New failure theories are constantly emerging in this field, some of which have been widely accepted and employed in industry to guide the design of composite structures.1 Presently, the rapid growth of composite applications in various industries requires new failure prediction techniques with the capabilities of dealing with three-dimensional (3D) loadings, explaining the nonlinear constituent behaviors, and predicting initial and final failures. For example, the increasing use of thick composites in pressure vessels, aerospace structures, civil constructions, and other industries makes the plane stress assumption invalid. As such, the behavior of thick composites under through-thickness loading should be taken into consideration.

Recently, a new failure theory called the micromechanics of failure (MMF) was proposed in order to meet the new challenges mentioned above.2 This method is based on a unit cell model that describes the microstructure of the composite and an independent failure criterion for each constituent. Based on a 3D unit cell model, the MMF is intrinsically 3D and capable of distinguishing vital constituents in critical ply in a composite laminate of any stacking sequence under fully 3D loadings. However, based on the data from a large number of experiments, the assumption that the constituent (both fiber and matrix) behaviors were linear elastic did not hold true under transverse and shear loading: the material exhibited considerable nonlinearity. Therefore, the MMF theory was combined with a progressive damage model for the polymeric matrix, which is the major contributor of nonlinearity.

The First World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-I) has successfully closed.3 It reflected the evolution in failure theory for composite materials in the past decade. The WWFE-II is presently open and offers researchers an excellent opportunity to demonstrate and update their failure theories. There are a total of 12 test cases in WWFE-II and they involve 5 different fiber–matrix systems. In most cases, the material (either unidirectional (UD) or multi-directional laminate) is subject to 3D loading conditions. The MMF would be an ideal tool to perform failure predictions for composites under such 3D loadings.

sec.title: Micromechanics of failure and the progressive damage model
Micro stress and macro stress
sec.p:
In order to simulate the microstructure of one lamina in terms of its fiber, matrix and interface, a unit cell model was used (Figure 1). With this model, the constituent level behavior was directly related to the ply behavior. In general, carbon fibers are transversely isotropic, while glass fibers are isotropic. Both fibers were assumed to be linear elastic and brittle. On the other hand, the matrix was isotropic and ductile. It exhibited nonlinear behavior once it was damaged. The interface was modeled with linear traction-separation behavior.4 In this article, we used a unit cell of the hexagonally packed array, as shown in Figure 1, because it outperforms other fiber arrangements in many aspects.5 Figure 1.
Unit cell model (hexagonally packed array).

Though the UD ply was generally considered to be transversely isotropic, both the strain/stress distribution within the fiber and the matrix, as well as the interfacial traction distribution along the fiber–matrix interface, must be nonuniform even under uniform external loading conditions. This is due to inhomogeneities at the micro level. A detailed distribution of how micro stresses are related to macro stresses and temperature increment can be given as6 (1)σf=Mfσ¯+AfΔTσm=Mmσ¯+AmΔTt=Miσ¯+AiΔT where M and A are stress amplification factors (SAF) that can be determined through direct finite element analysis of a unit cell with proper boundary conditions. For a given scenario of fiber arrangement and constituent properties, the SAF at each point on the cross-section of the unit cell was uniquely determined and independent of the macro stresses applied to the unit cell.

sec.title: Constituent failure criteria and the progressive damage model
Fiber failure criteria
sec.p: A complete set of constituent failure criteria has been proposed.2 In order to take the orthotropy of a carbon fiber into account, a quadratic failure criterion, whose form was suggested by the Tsai–Wu failure criterion, was proposed. (2)∑j=1 6∑i=1 6Fijσfiσfj+∑i=1 6Fiσfi≥1 where Fij and Fi are coefficients determined by the fiber strengths, including the longitudinal/transverse and tensile/compressive strengths, as well as the in-plane/transverse shear strengths. In reality, there is as of yet no reliable way of measuring most of these values. Thus, this criterion was impractical. Therefore, a maximum longitudinal stress failure criterion was used as the fiber failure criterion because fiber breakage was critical in the longitudinal direction of a lamina. (3)σf1≥Tf OR σf1≤-Cf where Tf and Cf denote the fiber longitudinal tensile and compressive strengths, respectively.

sec.title: Matrix failure criterion
sec.p: As the majority of matrix materials are isotropic, they possess different tensile and compressive strengths. Numerous experiments have shown that crazing or failure in the matrix is more sensitive to tensile stresses rather than compressive stresses. Such different tensile and compressive strengths indicate that matrix failure depends not only on the deviatoric stress invariant, i.e. the von Mises equivalent stress, σVM, but also on the volumetric stress invariant, i.e. the first stress invariant, I1. Raghava et al. [7] suggested a modified version of the von Mises failure criterion in terms of the initial tensile strength, Tmi, and the compressive strength, Cmi. (4)σVM 2CmiTmi+(1Tmi-1Cmi)I1≥1 where I1 and σVM can be respectively calculated from stress components using the following equation (5)I1=σm1+σm2+σm3σVM= (12[(σm1-σm2)2+(σm2-σm3)2 + (σm3-σm1)2+3(σm4 2+σm5 2+σm6 2)] )

This failure criterion is comparable to the condition that an equivalent stress, σeq, reaches the initial tensile strength, Tmi. (6)σeq=(β-1)I1+(β-1)2I1 2+4βσVM 22β where β is defined as the ratio of the compressive and tensile strengths. The equivalent stress is often called the Stassi’s stress.8

sec.title: Interface failure criterion
sec.p: We also proposed a quadratic failure criterion for the fiber–matrix interface. This criterion takes the following form (7)(átnñYn)2+(tsYs)2≥1

If the condition in equation (7) was satisfied, damage was initiated at the interface and the damaged zone exhibited softening behavior until complete interfacial separation was achieved. However, in this article we simply assumed that the bonding between the fiber and the matrix was sufficiently strong so that no separation at the interfacial region was produced. This is often true if a proper surface treatment is performed in order to enhance the interfacial strength.

sec.title: Damage model for the matrix
sec.p: Once the matrix failure criterion is satisfied, damage starts to develop and the stiffness of the matrix reduces by the amount of damage accumulated inside the matrix. When the damage is considered isotropic, the stress–strain relationship of the matrix is given as (8)σm=(1-Dm)Cmɛm where the damage factor, Dm, must range from 0 to 1. After the initiation of failure, the relationship between the equivalent stress, σeq and the damage factor, Dm, is described by the following equation (9)Dm={0κm<Tmi1-exp[γ(1-κmTmi)]Tmi≤κm≤Tmf} where κm is a scalar history variable recording the highest matrix equivalent stress ever attained. A stress–strain relationship is complemented by a damage loading function (10)f(σeq,κ)=σeq-κm
Damage initiation and evolution is controlled by the Kuhn–Tucker loading–unloading condition. (11)f≤0 κ·m≥0 fκ·m=0

Final fracture usually occurs before the damage factor, Dm, becomes unity. This value can be determined from the uniaxial tensile stress–strain curve. A value of 0.4 was used as a practical value for the rupture criterion of a damaged material.9

The overall scenario which combines MMF and the progressive damage model is shown in Figure 2. At the beginning of one global time increment i, we first calculated the total macro strain ɛ¯(i), after the current time increment. This represents a summation of the total macro strain before the current time increment ɛ¯(i-1), and the macro strain increment Δɛ¯(i). Next, we calculated the macro stress σ¯(i), based on the previous effective ply stiffness C¯(i-1) and ɛ¯(i). Then the micro stresses in the fiber σ¯f (i), and in the matrix σ¯m (i), due to the macro stress and the temperature increment were calculated. The subsequent procedures involved the following: application of the constituent failure criteria to both the fiber and the matrix, determining the respective failure indices, employing the progressive damage model to acquire the degraded fiber and matrix moduli, and calculating the effective ply stiffness through the micromechanical model for the next global time increment. The calculations were performed with the commercial FEA software MD Nastran combined with the user-defined subroutines UFAIL and UPROGFAIL.10 Abaqus 6.7-1 was also combined with the user-defined subroutine UMAT.11 Figure 2.
Overall algorithm combining the MMF and the progressive damage mechanics. MMF: micromechanics of failure.

For the numerical calculations, we were provided with the properties of the UD, the fiber and the matrix, and several stress–strain curves for the UD/matrix. However, certain properties were not consistent. For instance, the behavior of matrix PR319 and the epoxy1 was taken as linear (according to the instructions), but the in-plane shear stress–strain curves of UD T300/PR319 and AS carbon/epoxy1 were nonlinear. Therefore, we deliberately modified several constituent properties. The fiber and matrix properties used for the predictions of failure are listed in Tables 1 and 2, respectively. The predicted UD properties are listed in Table 3. Table 1.
Mechanical properties of fibers.12

Figure 3 shows our prediction of the transverse tensile, transverse compressive, and in-plane shear behaviors for all five UD laminates. These were attained using the algorithm described in Figure 2. The predicted curves were plotted together with their experimental counterparts for the transverse compressive and in-plane shear loadings (we were not provided with test curves for the transverse tensions). For all five laminae, the predicted final in-plane shear failure strains were smaller than their corresponding experimental values. In Figure 3(a), (b), and (d), overestimated final transverse compressive strengths and final transverse compressive failure strains were observed. Despite these disadvantages, the prediction generally agreed well with the test results in other aspects. Figure 3.
Predicted stress–strain curves for five types of UD laminae: (a) IM7/8551-7; (b) T300/PR-319; (c) AS carbon/Epoxy1; (d) S-glass/Epoxy2; (e) E-glass/MY750; (f) schematic representation of the loading directions. UD: unidirectional.

sec.title: Boundary conditions
sec.p:
Although the failure prediction of a composite laminate does not involve complex geometries (a simple block was used to represent the lamina/laminate in our analysis, as shown in Figure 4), proper boundary conditions are still critical to ensure the validity of the prediction. The periodical boundary conditions have been thoroughly discussed by Li et al.,12–14 and the following periodic boundary conditions were applied to the block (12)f≤0 κ·m≥0 fκ·m=0 Figure 4.
Illustration of the block representing the composite lamina/laminate used in the FEA.
FEA: finite element analysis.
For a multi-directional laminate under 3D loading, the boundary surfaces of the block may show undulations due to the nonuniform strain field through thickness.

sec.title: Results of prediction
sec.p: The MMF model has been employed to solve all the 12 test cases of the WWFE-II.15 These test cases cover (a) pure epoxy resin (test case 1), (b) UD laminae (test cases 2–7), and (c) multidirectional laminates (test cases 8–12). Note that in this exercise the local (on-axis) coordinate system for a single lamina is denoted by 1-2-3, while the global (off-axis) coordinate system for a multidirectional laminate is denoted by x − y − z. Accordingly, for UD laminates the local and global coordinate systems are coincident, which indicate that for UD laminates stress components σ1, σ2 and σ3 are the same as σx, σy and σz, respectively.

sec.title: Test case 1
sec.p:
The first test case was to plot the failure envelope of the pure epoxy resin MY750 under triaxial normal stresses. Both theoretical derivations and experimental results have shown that the pronounced nonlinear behavior of the UD under transverse and shear loading is attributed to the nonlinear behavior of matrix. Therefore, the first step toward an accurate prediction of UD failure was to predict the nonlinear behavior of the matrix. Figure 5 shows the failure envelopes of the epoxy resin MY750, as predicted by the matrix failure criterion in MMF and the progressive damage model. The inner envelope marked with dashed line indicates the initial failure, while the outer envelope appearing in the solid line represents the final failure of the matrix. There was no obvious distinction between the shapes of the initial and final failure envelopes. Furthermore, the initial and final failure envelopes were unbounded in a certain region of the third quadrant where σx and σy (and σz) were approximately equal. This implied that, based on the matrix failure criterion currently employed in MMF, the pure matrix would not fail under triaxial compression, when the deviatoric stress was negligibly small compared to the hydrostatic pressure. Figure 5.
Failure envelope of the stress σx versus the stress σy (with σy = σz) for the polymeric resin matrix (MY750).

sec.title: Test cases 2 and 3
sec.p:
Figures 6 and 7 respectively show the failure envelopes of the in-plane shear stress and strain versus the hydrostatic stress (σx = σy = σz) for the UD made of T300/PR319. The figures correspond to test cases 2 and 3, respectively. Under this loading condition, both the initial and final ply failures were caused by failure of the matrix. Since the matrix was quite strong under hydrostatic pressure, as shown in Figure 5, both the initial and final failure envelopes enclosed much more area in the second quadrant than in the first. In addition, the offset of the final failure envelope from the initial envelope increased in the second quadrant. Figure 6.
Failure envelope of the in-plane shear stress, τ12, versus the transverse stress, σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3) for a UD carbon/epoxy (T300/PR319).
UD: unidirectional. Figure 7.
Failure envelope of the in-plane shear strain, γ12, versus the transverse stress, σ2 (with σ1 = σ2 = σ3) for a UD carbon/epoxy (T300/PR319).
UD: unidirectional.

sec.title: Test case 4
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the in-plane shear stress–strain curve of the T300/PR319 lamina under a hydrostatic pressure of 600 MPa. This corresponds to test case 4, in which the loading path was different from the previous two cases. The hydrostatic pressure was increased from 0 to 600 MPa. Then, while the hydrostatic pressure was held constant, the in-plane shear stress was increased until the final failure occurred. Since the first portion of the in-plane shear stress–strain curve was linear, we inferred that under a hydrostatic pressure of 600 MPa, the ply remained intact. According to the stress–strain curve in Figure 8, the initial in-plane shear strength and failure strain were about 81 MPa and 5.8%, respectively. The final in-plane shear strength and failure strain were approximately 123 MPa and 11.9%, respectively. Both initial and final failures were due to failure of the matrix. Figure 8.
Shear stress–strain curve (τ12 versus γ12) for a UD carbon/epoxy (T300/PR319) under σ1 = σ2 = σ3 = −600 MPa.
UD: unidirectional.

sec.title: Test case 5
sec.p:
Figure 9 shows the failure envelope of σ2 versus σ3 (with σ1 = σ3) for a UD made of E-glass/MY750, corresponding to test case 5. In the first, second and fourth quadrants, both the initial and final ply failures were caused by matrix failure. In the third quadrant, failure of the matrix was still dominant, with the exception of small regions of high hydrostatic pressure where the fiber fails first (marked on Figure 9). The compressive stress in the longitudinal direction of the fiber increased the hydrostatic stress in the matrix, resulting in a higher strength when compared to a state of transverse biaxial loading. It was also observed that, due to stress amplification, the deviatoric stresses in the matrix served to lower the strengths in the third quadrant. The identical initial and final failure zones in the third quadrant implied that failure occurred due to fiber compression. Figure 9.
Failure envelope of the transverse stress, σ2, versus the through-thickness stress, σ3 (with σ1 = σ3) for a UD glass/epoxy (E-glass/MY750).
UD: unidirectional.

sec.title: Test cases 6 and 7
sec.p:
Shown in Figures 10 and 11 are the failure envelopes of σ1 versus σ3 (with σ2 = σ3) for a UD made of S-glass/epoxy2 and AS carbon/epoxy1, respectively, which correspond to test cases 6 and 7, respectively. Although two different fiber/matrix systems were used in the two test cases, the obtained failure envelopes shared several features when subjected to the same loading conditions. The final failure envelopes in both figures are quadrilateral, with top and bottom edges resulting from final matrix failure, while the left and right edges (mostly) are the result of fiber breakage. Nevertheless, due to the large difference in the mechanical behavior of the two matrices used in the test cases, the initial failure envelopes in the two figures are significantly different. In Figure 10, since the stress–strain curves of the Epoxy 2 matrix show noticeable nonlinearity, the shape of the initial failure envelope resembles a tilted partial ellipse. In Figure 11, the initial and final envelopes nearly overlap, owing to the brittle behavior of the AS carbon/epoxy1 in the transverse direction. Figure 10.
Failure envelope of the longitudinal stress, σ1, versus the through-thickness stress, σ3 (with σ2 = σ3) for a UD glass/epoxy (S-glass/epoxy2).
UD: unidirectional. Figure 11.
Failure envelope of the longitudinal stress, σ1, versus the through-thickness stress, σ3 (with σ2 = σ3) for a UD carbon/epoxy (AS carbon/epoxy1).
UD: unidirectional.

sec.title: Test case 8
sec.p:
Starting from Figure 12, which corresponds to test case 8, all the results displayed in the subsequent figures are from multi-directional laminates. Figure 12 shows the failure envelopes of σy versus σz (with σx = σz) for a [±35°]2S laminate comprises E-glass/MY750. Both the initial and final ply failures were induced by matrix failure. Figure 12.
Failure envelope of the axial stress, σy, versus the through-thickness stress, σz (with σx = σz) for a [±35°]2S glass/epoxy (E-glass/MY750) laminate.

sec.title: Test case 9
sec.p:
Figure 13 shows the compressive stress–strain curves σy − εx and σy − εy under σx = σz = −100 MPa for a [±35°]2S laminate comprising E-glass/MY750. This corresponds to test case 9. Both curves have an apparent turning point at σy = −100 MPa, which is a natural consequence of the loading process. First, the hydrostatic pressure applied to the laminate was increased from 0 to 100 MPa. Then, the compressive stress in the y-direction was constantly increased while the compressive stresses in the other two directions were maintained at −100 MPa until the final failure occurred. By observing the curves between 0 and −100 MPa, we can easily conclude that the x-direction was stiffer than the y-direction. Since the compressive stresses in the x- and z-directions remained unchanged at −100 MPa, the σy–εy curve exhibits much softer behavior after σy reaches −100 MPa. The curves between −100 MPa and the initial failure points are linear, indicating that the laminate remained intact in this region. Meanwhile, due to Poisson’s effect, the strain in the x-direction increased after σy reaches −100 MPa and σy eventually became positive when the final failure occurred. Figure 13.
Axial compressive stress–strain curves (σy − εx and σy − εy) for a [±35°]2S glass/epoxy (E-glass/MY750) laminate under σx = σz = −100 MPa.

sec.title: Test cases 10 and 11
sec.p:
Figures 14 and 15 show the failure envelopes of τyz versus σz (with σx = σy = 0) for [0°/90°/±45°]S and [0°/90°]2S laminates made of IM7/8551-7, respectively. These correspond to test cases 10 and 11. All ply failures were caused by matrix failures. The basic shapes of the initial and final failure envelopes in Figures 14 and 15 are similar to that shown in Figure 6. The plot area of Figure 14 is divided into three sectors by dotted lines: the initial and final failures in the middle sector were caused by matrix failures in the ±45° and 0° plies, while failure in the other two sectors was due to matrix failures in the ±45° plies only. In Figure 15, all laminate failures were attributed to matrix failures in the 0° plies, with the exception that laminate failure under the pure through-thickness stress (either tension or compression) resulted from matrix failures in all the plies. Figure 14.
Failure envelope of the through-thickness shear stress, τyz, versus the through-thickness stress, σz (with σx = σy = 0) for the [0°/90°/±45°]S carbon/epoxy (IM7/8551-7) laminate. Figure 15.
Failure envelope of the through-thickness shear stress, τyz, versus the through-thickness stress, σz (with σx = σy = 0) for the [0°/90°]2S carbon/epoxy (IM7/8551-7) laminate.

sec.title: Test case 12
sec.p:
Figure 16 shows the stress–strain curves σz − εz, σz − εx and σz − εy for the [0°/90°]2S laminate comprised of IM7/8551-7 laminate when σx = σy = 0. In the through-thickness direction, the σz − εz curve exhibited remarkable nonlinear behavior after the initial failure, whereas in the x- and y-directions the stress–strain curves were identical. This was due to the equivalence of the lay-up sequences in these two directions. Furthermore, σz − εx and σz − εy did not show observable nonlinearity because of the high longitudinal stiffness of the ply in the x- and y-directions. Figure 16.
Compressive through-thickness stress–strain curves (σz − εz, σz − εx and σz − εy) for the [0°/90°]2S carbon/epoxy (IM7/8551-7) laminate when σx = σy = 0.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Through-thickness stresses are usually neglected for problems involving a thin composite laminate. However, the existence of through-thickness stresses will substantially influence the failure status of a thick composite laminate. With the increased industrial application of thick composites, the ability to perform failure prediction of a composite laminate under fully 3D external loading is of great significance. Using current MMF theory and the progressive damage model, we were able to predict the nonlinear mechanical behavior of UD and multi-directional laminates under various loading conditions, once the nonlinear behavior of the matrix was known. In this article, we presented our predictions for 12 test cases in WWFE-II. These cases involved both UD and multi-directional laminates made of five different fiber/matrix systems subjected to 3D loading conditions. In the authors’ view, these cases were excellent examples for revealing the strengths of the current MMF methodology. However, further improvements need to be realized so that the MMF theory is more robust and adaptable. The current MMF theory is based on linear elasticity, which could be less accurate and less realistic. Nevertheless, its full 3D capability allowed us to obtain prediction results with little difficulty. We are constantly updating the MMF theory as well as the progressive damage model in order to provide more accurate failure prediction with less effort.

It is worth pointing out that theoretical results obtained from the MMF theory have been compared with those from other theories in Kaddour and Hinton.16 In addition, the MMF predictions will be compared with experimental data in a future publication, as a part of Part B of the WWFE-II.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The development of the MMF has been partially funded by AFOSR with Dr Charles Lee as a technical monitor. This work was also supported by Hanyang University.

ack.title: Acknowledgement
ack.p: The authors thank the Stanford Composites Design Team headed by Prof. Stephen Tsai at Stanford University for technical discussion and collaboration.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.

sec.title: Subscripts
sec.p: Contracted notation is used for stress and strain components.
